repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series: Blaschka Models; and Unprocessed accessions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains graduate brochures from the Biology Department, glass models created by the Blaschka Company, and a Barnum video.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Department of Biology emerged from its predecessor, the Department of Natural History. The Department was founded in 1892 and began offering undergraduate students the option of a departmental major in 1894. In the same year, the Department established its Ph.D. program.

The Department of Biology began offering a summer school program in 1898. This summer school program operated off-site, away from the Tufts campus in Medford. Established in South Harpswell, Maine near the shore of Casco Bay, this summer school program continued for several years until the facilities it utilized were sold.
The Department of Biology conferred four Ph.D. degrees by 1906. During the 1906-1907 academic year, the M.S. degree in biology began to be offered by the Department.

The Department of Biology expanded in 1933 when the university administration authorized the construction of a greenhouse in Barnum museum for its use. Later, during the 1934-1935 academic year, the construction of the east wing of the Barnum Museum was completed, thereby expanding the physical size of the Department of Biology. In 1966, the Department of Biology collaborated in the introduction of an interdisciplinary Ph.D. program in the Molecular Basis of Biological Phenomena on the Medford campus.

The night of April 14, 1975 proved to be a momentous one for the Department of Biology. On that night, a fire believed to have been caused by an electrical malfunction in a refrigeration unit resulted in the wholesale destruction of the original section of the old Barnum Museum (which the Department of Biology had largely occupied).

In addition to the loss of valuable materials, books, and laboratory animals, this disastrous fire succeeded in destroying the invaluable research materials which had been accumulated by two leading faculty members in the Department. Professors Benjamin Dane and Norton Nickerson suffered irretrievable losses to their scholarship in this fire. Professor Dane lost hundreds of feet of film documenting his research while Professor Nickerson was faced with the total destruction of his herbarium.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for access. This collection may require review before it is available for use. Please contact DCA for further details.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Copyright to all materials created by Tufts University employees in the course of their work is held by the Trustees of Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Blaschka Glass Model Collection. These glass models of invertebrates were given to Tufts by P.T. Barnum in 1885 as a part of the Barnum Museum of Natural History. They were returned to Tufts after being on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass. They are examples of models created by Bohemian glassmakers Leopold and Rudolf Blaschka.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One broken tentacle found in a separate storage box. Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [The largest of the Blaschka models at Tufts, a clear-topped jellyfish with long blue and pink dangling tentacles.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. Includes one broken arm. [Clear spiny tentacles sprouting from mushroom-like base. No label on base.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [Figure has five squiggly legs with spiky detailing. Yellowish in color.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [A small clear tube with whitish stripes on internal glass section. One figure is rounded on both ends, and one ends in two points.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [A small clear tube with whitish stripes on internal glass section. One figure is rounded on both ends, and one ends in two points.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [This figure is clear, almost polka-dotted glass ith a fin on one side and another more colorful, bulbous appendage on the other. There is a pink line running through the body and a small glass tail on the end.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Labels read: "Coelenterata Sea Anemone: an Anthozoan" and "Aiptasia diaphana Rapp. Nr. 24." Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [This figure is brownish in tint with spikes emerging from mushroom-like base. The base of this figure is labelled. This figure is similar to Coelenterata (Sea Anemone) but it is smaller and thinner.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [A flat yellowish figure.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Object was on loan to the Corning Museum of Glass from 1962 until 2004. [A pinkish squid-like figure with eyes and two long tentacles.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Includes enlarged model and actual size model." Actual-sized model is partially broken. Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. Conservation efforts made at Tufts University by Stephen Koob, Conservator at Corning Museum of Glass on December 5th, 2008. [A small snail-like figure with spiky appendages coming out of one end.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Alcyonium is a colonial form occuring below low tide mark, attached to stones in various sizes and shapes. The polyps project in life from the general surface of the colony." 2 models are missing a number of fragments. Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [There are two figures in this set, a small clear palm tree-like figure and a branch of clear glass with yellowish spiny appendages that look like smaller versions of the palm tree.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Alcyonium is a colonial form occuring below low tide mark, attached to stones in various sizes and shapes. The polyps project in life from the general surface of the colony." 2 models are missing a number of fragments. Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [There are two figures in this set, a small clear palm tree-like figure and a branch of clear glass with yellowish spiny appendages that look like smaller versions of the palm tree.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Alcyonium is a colonial form occuring below low tide mark, attached to stones in various sizes and shapes. The polyps project in life from the general surface of the colony." 2 models are missing a number of fragments. Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [There are two figures in this set, a small clear palm tree-like figure and a branch of clear glass with yellowish spiny appendages that look like smaller versions of the palm tree.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Alcyonium is a colonial form occuring below low tide mark, attached to stones in various sizes and shapes. The polyps project in life from the general surface of the colony." 2 models are missing a number of fragments. Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [There are two figures in this set, a small clear palm tree-like figure and a branch of clear glass with yellowish spiny appendages that look like smaller versions of the palm tree.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [This figure is mustard-colored with numerous spikes. The body thins and ends in a side that resembles a bouquet of flowers.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Lesson Nr. 271." Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [This figure is pink in tint. Worm-like with a spiky texture and a spiky head on one side.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "A worm with some appendages modified as gills. Polychaeta." Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [A greenish worm-like figure with small clear cilia-like glass appendages on the sides. The body of the figure thins and transitions into clear glass.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Rolando. Nr. 342". Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [The figure is a bulbous blue orb with a long tail that splits into two sections at the end.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [A clear body with pink-tinted internal organs and wing-like structures on one side. ]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Favorinus albus, A. & H." Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [A very spiky caterpillar-like figure, yellowish in color with a clear head and two antennae.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "Red coral: the coral of industry (enlargement at right)." Picked up from Barnum Hall Laboratory, Department of Biology by DCA on June 10th, 2008. [Two figures, one enlargement nd one coral branch. Both are pink in color. The enlargement is a pink tube with a palm-tree like structure coming off of the side. ]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Label reads: "? does not belong to coelenterara (sic)"
